title: 104_s1993
content: The Act titled "Federal Reserve Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1996" requires non-monetary policy spending to be subject to congressional appropriations. The Comptroller General, in consultation with the Board, must identify functions related to monetary policy. A report must be submitted to Congress by April 30, 1997. After September 30, 1997, all expenditures by the Board or Federal reserve bank must be approved in advance, except for funds related to monetary policy. The conduct of monetary policy is not subject to advance appropriations. The Comptroller General must submit an annual report to Congress on the Federal Reserve System's compliance with this requirement. SEC. 3. TREATMENT OF SURPLUS ACCOUNT. Termination of Surplus Account Authorization: Amendments to the Federal Reserve Act include removing surplus funds, stockholder dividends, and returning funds within 30 days of enactment. Federal reserve banks must transfer funds held in surplus accounts to the Secretary of the Treasury. The Comptroller General determines the percentage of net earnings to be transferred annually to the Treasury. A report on this determination is due within 6 months of the Act's enactment. Upon enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General of the United States will report its determination to Congress, along with any recommendations for legislative action. SEC. 4. ANNUAL INDEPENDENT AUDITS. Each Federal reserve bank must annually obtain an audit from an independent certified public accountant who meets Board qualifications. The auditor must certify their independence and use accepted auditing standards. The audit must be completed within 30 days and certified by the Federal Reserve Bank. After each audit, the Federal Reserve Bank must provide a certification to the Comptroller General of the United States, confirming compliance with audit requirements and providing proof of audit report receipt. Each Federal Reserve Bank must also submit the audit to the Board or an independent auditor designated by the Board. The Board must annually obtain an audit of all Federal reserve banks' financial statements from an independent auditor, in consultation with the Comptroller General of the United States, using generally accepted accounting standards. SEC. 5. APPLICABILITY OF FEDERAL PROCUREMENT PROCEDURES. This section applies certain provisions of law to the Board and Federal reserve banks as if they were executive agencies. Effective date is October 1, 1996. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The term "Board" refers to the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, and the term "Federal reserve bank" has the same meaning as in the Federal Reserve Act.
